conclusion: Analyzing internal energy at states a and c for an ideal gas in adiabatic and isochoric processes.
Path c → d: Adiabatic expansion (pressure decreases, volume increases).
Path d → a: Isochoric cooling (pressure decreases, volume constant).
Path a → b: Adiabatic compression (pressure increases, volume decreases).
Path b → c: Isochoric heating (pressure increases, volume constant).
Internal energy U depends only on temperature for an ideal gas.
For isochoric processes, ΔU = Q (heat added equals change in internal energy).
For adiabatic processes, Q = 0 (no heat transfer).
States a and c are at the same vertical lines as states b and d respectively, meaning Volume at a = Volume at d and Volume at b = Volume at c.
State c has higher pressure than state a at their respective volumes.
For an ideal gas, P ∝ T at constant volume (from PV = nRT).
Since Pc > Pa and Vc < Va, this means Tc > Ta.
Since internal energy U ∝ T for an ideal gas, and Tc > Ta, the internal energy at state c is greater than the internal energy at state a (Uc > Ua).
